title: coronavirus women equal leadership
story: AS I have often pointed out, there are many reasons why women make good leaders.In my experience, they tend to be good collaborators because their ego is unlikely to interfere with letting other people have good ideas, and be able to voice them and take credit for them.Their emotional intelligence and empathy makes them excellent communicators.But it’s not just my view that women are good leaders. Many studies show women are more focused on building community and teams.They are more likely than men to cultivate a erse set of advisers to help them succeed. They are also more likely to follow advice.A study by management consulting firm McKinsey found that women are more people- orientated and spend more time developing and coaching other leaders in their organisation. In other words, they don’t need to reserve all the glory for themselves.There is something  at play too, though. Female leaders are more likely to be blameddecisions are unpopular or ineffective. They are questioned and second-guessed more often than men.But then Covid- entered the equation and presented world leaders with a new challenge — an invisible enemy that is highly contagious, unpredictable and deadly.This pandemic has been an unprecedented test for all concerned.And guess what  A disproportionate number of those who have passed this test — countries such as Germany, New Zealand, Iceland and Finland — have women at the helm.It is not exclusively female-led countries that are doing well, of course. But bearing in mind only seven per cent of all world leaders are women, about  per cent of countries led by women are doing well when it comes to containing Covid-. Global health experts have concluded that one thing that has led to success in tackling coronavirus is — speed.Prof Tom Bollyky, director of global health programme at US think-tank the Council on Foreign Relations, said: “Countries that have not dithered in their response, that have mobilised quickly, have done well.”New Zealand’s PM Jacinda Ardern put it simply: “Go hard and go early.”The number of Covid--related deaths is predicted to be substantially lower in areas where leaders acted sooner, even by a week, because they flattened the curve and prevented new cases.Many women acted first and made the brave decision to shut down le as we knew it, even though that was an unpopular thing to do.But it seems women leaders are listening to World Health Organisation advice and also looking at other countries for guidance.They don’t think they have all the answers but women are able to put their ego to one side and let experts guide them — something which cannot be said of Donald Trump.Incidentally, I have not seen any women leaders making unfounded or dangerous suggestions about possible cures. Can you imagine a woman leader suggesting that people inject Dettol into themselves, as dingbat Trump recently suggested Or can you imagine a woman suggesting to people that they can fight coronavirus and winthey are strong enough This pandemic is not a battle to be fought and won. It is a virus, which can affect literally anyone.No one knows how they will be affected and that bullish “fight it” approach is, in my experience, very male. Conversely, the decision to protect everyone, putting the most at risk first, is more female.It’s interesting that some male leaders seem more interested in covering up the problems. Like Donald Trump, who thinks he is an expert on everything and more fixated on garnering praise for what he has done than fixing and getting right what has not gone so well.I know I am talking in generalisations here but my experience of women is that we want to understand the mistakes and fix them, not cover them up.This pandemic has been full of dficulty and tragedy for everyone.But perhaps one good thing that will come out of it is that the world will acknowledge women deserve an equal  when it comes to leadership.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.FORMER Love Islander Montana Brown this week posted some “Instagram vs reality” pictures ­– one of her in a lacy bralette and silky shorts, the other in a cute pink PJ set.But I couldn’t help but notice that she is wearing  eyelashes and full make-up in bed – in both sets.The very idea of wearing make-up, let alone  eyelashes at the moment, is unimaginable – especially to go to sleep.A far more realistic picture of my le at present, in fact, is that I am mainly wearing pyjamas all day as well as in bed.HAS anyone  been watching Madonna’s “Quarantine Diaries” on Instagram This week she said she has coronavirus antibodies, having been tested for the virus.And her conclusion in the face of this discovery  “Tomorrow, I’m going to go for a long drive in a car and I’m going to roll down the window, and I’m going to breathe in the Covid- air,” she says.Sorry, but what  No one knows yet whether it’s possible to have coronavirus more than once and the presence of antibodies may not provide protection against the disease.This seems like a risk no one should be advocating.The bonny baby, who has already inherited his father’s hair, was named after both their grandfathers and the doctor who saved Boris’s le.A wonderful and touching gesture.Wilfred, a name not popular since the s, takes its roots from “will” and “peace”, two words very apt for these dficult times.HUGE congratulations to Gigi Hadid and Zayn Malik, who confirmed this week they are expecting a baby.I guess the lockdown baby boom has already started, which just proves that le goes on.What a beautul baby they will have.It’s great to have some good news amid the gloom.WHAT a month it’s been for Boris Johnson.For the past few weeks he has faced professional challenges far bigger than those he may have anticipated when he was first elected Prime Minister.Not only that, but he has also survived time in intensive care suffering from coronavirus. And now he is a father yet again at .I think it’s fair to say that this period will go down in his own personal history as perhaps some of the most memorable few weeks of his le.EVEN the most hardened climate change denier cannot fail to pause for thought at the before and after photos of the Solent.Aerial shots of this part of Britain’s coastline look more like pictures that have been taken in the Caribbean.The water is so blue and so clean that it looks positively tropical. In fact, it’s unrecognisable after just six weeks of lockdown.The images show how the usually murky waters of the UK coastline have been transformed, which must surely be due in part to a reduction in pollution since the coronavirus pandemic stopped leisure traffic on the Solent.But other astonishing photos from all over the world have surfaced recently too.Pollution-free images of landmarks in Delhi and Beijing, which are all too often seen shimmering under a haze of smog, are a real reminder of our role in creating pollution and also in reducing it.Imagineanother silver lining to this terrible pandemic was that we all began to understand the effects of our impact on the environment, and that we took the threat of climate change more seriously – and started to take responsibility for changing our ways.I AM as keen as the next person to regain my freedom, and for things to begin toto normal.But I cannot be the only one who gave a shudder at the thought of being allowed to choose a “bubble” of just ten family members as friends, as was hinted at by some.Can you even imagine the disputes, upsets and hurt feelings that would result all over the landyour chosen bubble had chosen another group to huddle with In fact, that rule would likely cause so much offence that we would only have ten friends left. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: china truth coronavirus truth opinion
story: AN emotional Boris Johnson described how close he came to leaving this world, just as his new baby son was about to enter it.He was near tears as he told The Sun on Sunday’s David Wooding about the moment he realised he might die. “I’m a very lucky man,” he said.Our Prime Minister was indeed lucky.He was almost killed by a hideous bug we have learned to call coronavirus. Or Covid-.It should be known unflinchingly as “Chinese flu”.This virus was born in China, covered up by China, spread worldwide by China.In American bric-a-brac shops you will see signs saying: “You break it, you own it.” Covid- is owned by China.Chinese flu has paralysed the global economy, brought poverty to whole nations and increased the risk of death and disaster across the planet from other causes.The world is in lockdown, we are wearing face masks and latex gloves, avoiding friends and family, thanks to China.To avoid perhaps even more lethal pandemics, China must be brought to book.Beijing must allow us to find out precisely how this virus escaped, whether from a leaky laboratory or its hideous wet markets in Wuhan.The first indication of coronavirus was monitored as far back as November last year.China must explain why it silenced the doctor who raised the alarm and why it allowed millions of Chinese New Year revellers to travel far and wide long after learning the disease spread from human to human.Far from addressing these issues, China is doing everything possible to wriggle off the hook.Belligerent attacks, sanctioned by the Chinese Communist Party, are levelled against any country or inidual who dares ask questions.In an extraordinary outburst, China’s ambassador to Canberra threatened to beggar the Australian economy by cutting off trade in coal and wine.Similar warnings have been heard in Germany about car exports.Their crime  To call for a transparent investigation into the origins of this lethal pandemic.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal. Beijing’s aggression is working.The EU allegedly watered down criticism of the regime in a major report on Covid-, a claim it denies.Other world leaders, hopelessly addicted to Chinese money, are terried of offending this economic juggernaut.But the first duty of every leader is to protect their people.US President Donald Trump cites top-level intelligence that this bug began le in the Wuhan Institute of Virology.Nobody wants to hear inconvenient truth from Trump.So as a near-death survivor, it now falls to Boris Johnson, with his freshly enhanced international authority, to pick up the baton and lead the world in demanding answers.As he told ministers at his first Cabinet meeting, quoting his Roman hero Cicero: “The health of the people comes first.”He can start once this crisis has subsided by cancelling Britain’s reckless deal to give China’s state-backed Huawei a role in building our new G broadband network.The idea that heavily subsidised Huawei is independent of Beijing’s snooping rulers was always absurd.After the Covid meltdown, there is zero chance Tory MPs will vote this through Parliament.The world, brave Australia included, is rapidly reviewing its reliance on cheap Chinese supply lines.Beijing will scream blue murder, of course.But as the Chinese like to say, every crisis presents an opportunity.Boris should make a virtue of necessity and turn this “new normal” attitude to China into official Government policy.The World Health Organisation, heavily reliant on Chinese cash and goodwill, is also in the dock.This UN body is supposed to protect the world from perils such as coronavirus.Instead, its pro-China leaders turned a blind eye until way too late.China must not be allowed to bully or buy its way out of this mess — or to “save face” at the expense of countless millions of lives, now or in the future.China must be held to account.Having left his death bed full of “terrible buoyancy”, Boris Johnson is just the man to do it.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for title: what is ve day victory europe
story: On May , , fighting drew to a halt as the Germans surrendered to the allies, marking the end of Adolf Hitler’s war and sparking celebrations around the world.VE Day - or Victory in Europe Day - honours the occasion each year.The event, which this year will coincide with the early May bank holiday, is regarded as one of the biggest celebrations in British history.It commemorates the formal acceptance of Nazi Germany’s surrender by the allied forces at the end of the Second World War.On  April , Adolf Hitler committed suicide.Karl Dönitz succeeded him as the German head of state, going on to negotiate an end to the war with the allied forces, which was made up of nations including Britain, the US, France and Russia.It heralded the beginning of the end of the Second World War, a conflict that cost millions of lives.The Queen will lead this years event with a special address to the nation followed by a nationwide singalong to Vera Lynn and indoor WWII-themed street parties.Public celebrations for the th anniversary of the Second World War were cancelled due to the coronavirus lockdown.But families are being urged to put up celebration bunting indoors and join together singing WWII song Well Meet Again by Dame Vera Lynn - in a nationwide celebration inspired by Clap For Carers.Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced the end of the war in Europe with a speech broadcast from Downing St on May  .In his famous address, he said: My dear friends, this is your hour.This is not victory of a party or of any class. It’s a victory of the great British nation as a whole.We were the first, in this ancient island, to draw the sword against tyranny.However, he then reminded them that the war was not yet won.At that point, Japan remained undefeated.King George VI also gave a speech, broadcast from bomb scarred Buckingham Palace, in which he thanked the nation.The war continued for several months as Japan didnt surrender at the same time as Germany.British and Commonwealth Armed Forces were still fighting in Burma, Singapore and Thailand.On August  and  , the United States dropped atomic bombs in Hiroshima and Nagasaki.On August , the Soviet Union declared war on Japan.The Japanese government on August  communicated its intention to surrender.Victory over Japan day - or VJ Day - takes place each year on August .The Second World War came to an end six years and one day after it started on September , , when official surrender documents were signed on the deck of the USS Missouri in Tokyo Bay by the Japanese.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meet three community heroes who are helping others
story: In times of trouble people need their best friends beside them, and that’s never more true than for the homeless community and their dogs.So when, in March, some of London’s nearly , rough sleepers were offered hotel accommodation to escape the ravages of the coronavirus pandemic, many were worried about leaving their canine companions behind.“Homeless people’s dogs are their leline,” says Michelle Clark, who founded Dogs on the Streetsfour years ago.The charity operates a mobile vet clinic for street dogs in London, offering check-ups, medication, leads, bowls, blankets and toys as well as a   freephone number for pets requiring urgent medical attention.“When the country went into lockdown we were approached by local councils as some of the hotels didn’t accept dogs,” Michelle, , from London, explains.“No problem – we’d just set up a -kennel sanctuary so we were able to tell rough sleepers that, while they stayed safe in hotels, we’d care for their pets. Still, saying goodbye to their companions was devastating for people. Their dogs are their company, love, loyalty and trust – their everything. Driving the dog away, I’d burst into tears.”Six weeks into lockdown the owners are missing their dogs, but Michelle sends them daily pictures and videos to reassure them.“Some of the dogs slept in the bottom of their owners’ sleeping bags so we bought sleeping bags for them to burrow into,” Michelle says. “Others preferred to be on top of duvets. Their kennels are heated and during the day we keep the dogs busy, playing in our three acres of grounds, so there’s no time to pine for their owners.”One dog – Miss L, a young husky – is a case in point. Her owner was distraught when he said goodbye to her – they’d been together since she was eight weeks old – and he was worried about how she’d cope without him. But Michelle discovered she loves cheese, which helped gain her trust, and now Miss L is settled in, making friends with fellow lockdown pups.Some homeless people, however, couldn’t face being parted from their canine companions so remained on the streets. Michelle and her team are there to support them too.“We’re operating the mobile clinic as a food bank for dogs, and the   emergency line,” Michelle says. “We’ve had people in dire financial straits contact us saying they can’t afford to keep their dogs and we’ve organised food parcels so they can stay together.”In the current crisis, working on the streets, Michelle and her volunteers are effectively on the front line. A medical supply company donated gloves and masks and Deborah Meaden sent hand sanitisers to help them.Still, Michelle has been diagnosed with pneumonia, possibly Covid- related, and is recovering at home with her ex-street dog Brock by her side while her team continue DOTS’ work.“I just want to get better and back out there, helping the homeless community,” Michelle says. “There will be some emotional reunions when this is over.”When British schools went into Covid- lockdown, a nationwide network of teachers, including Sandra Obike, stepped up to support NHS heroes.Sandra, who is head of design and technology at Swanlea School in east London, immediately put her skills and workspace to best use – first, sourcing spare unused personal protective equipmentthat could be donated to a nearby major hospital, and then using her school design and technologylab to create  brand new visors for key workers.And she isn’t alone – DT staff at more than  British schools are now collectively involved in the fight against Covid-, manufacturing and donating more than , items of vital PPE including visors, goggles, scrubs, masks and more.“We’ve been doing things since the very first week of lockdown, communicating using sites like Facebook, sharing resources and free design templates,” explains Sandra.“I asked our school headteacherwe could use the materials, space and machinery, and she instantly said yes. I also had a contact at Royal London Hospital, and asked: ‘Can I help  Would it be useful to have some visors ’, and she jumped at the chance.“I knew immediately that we had some unused PPE like goggles, aprons and gloves – so we sent that to the hospital at the start of April, so they were able to start using it as soon as possible.”Sandra, her boyfriend and one of her DT colleagues then set to work at school, creating new visors while safely observing social distancing. They used open-source design templates – provided for free by expert companies like Kitronik and Smoke  Mirrors, who’ve also been key to this Covid- effort – and their ingenuity with the materials they already had.“We were working pretty much like an assembly line, cutting the material, sterilising the parts, assembling it all and then bagging everything for delivery,” says Sandra.“As a teacher, I’m now working from home and interacting with students, but making visors was something I could do while still continuing my day-to-day job. I felt like it was something I could do in the interim, to keep key workers safe, while there was a shortage of PPE.”It’s clear that Sandra is passionate about her DT teaching profession: “We’re educating the engineers of the future,” she says.There’s also no doubt that creating visors is for her a very personal response: “A lot of my family members and friends work within the NHS, as doctors and nurses,” she says. “My mum is retired, but still helping out in a care home. As technologists, we’re problem-solvers – we try to work around the issue, and find a way to do things. For instance, we’ve got two large-scale laser cutters at our school, which meant we could cut quite a bit in a short scale of time, and some places have used D printers – so you work to the best ability that you’ve got.”Teamwork is at the heart of this story, too. This is about colleagues and collaborators, from dedicated DT teachers to suppliers who donate materials free of charge.“Social media has mobilised our effort, on a national scale,” says Sandra. “Where there is surplus, we’ll try to logistically pass it around the network across Britain. Seeing the sheer numbers of what people have done and contributed – that’s when it hits home how amazing this is.“As a teacher, this is a small thing I can do, so that someone who’s potentially putting their le at risk can go into a safer situation at work, and do something big. Everyone is working together for that common goal. It goes to show how much we love the NHS, and how much we want to step out to support them.”Big-hearted Brits are making a dference to other people’s lives every day in this time of crisis – and sometimes it’s the little things that mean the most.Five-year-old Lucy Dawson has been busy delivering handmade paper flowers to her neighbours in Fakenham in Norfolk – leaving them with a note on their doorsteps in the hope of raising a smile and lting people’s spirits during the lockdown.“I learnt to make the paper flowers at my breakfast and after-school club before the lockdown. I wanted to cheer people up,” Lucy says.Her parents, Shelley, , and Marc, , couldn’t be prouder of their daughter, who’s received chocolate and cards from grateful neighbours.Lucy says: “I felt happy and proud that I helped to cheer people up. It gave me happy tears.”Mum Shelley says: “Lucy is creative and loves crafting. She suggested leaving the flowers on doorsteps with a note as a little surprise.”For many neighbours, locked down until the coronavirus has passed, a surprise gt has been the highlight of their day.Lucy and her mum have been careful to observe social distancing and to make the doorstep deliveries during their daily exercise session, using plenty of hand sanitising gel along the way.Shelley says: “She’s a caring little girl. Her grandad Andrew, who’s , lives next door and we can’t see him at the moment. So she leaves handmade gts on his doorstep because she misses him so much.”One note from a neighbour was wrapped around a chocolate bar, and said: “This is just a little thank you from us, it made us smile and we really needed that today.”Dad Marc adds: “We’re extremely proud of what Lucy has done for her neighbours. The look on her face when she received the thank you gts and notes is something me and Shelley will never forget.”A neighbour who works as an AE nurse in King’s Lynn was especially touched when she discovered Lucy’s flowers on her doorstep. She and her family wrote a note of thanks.The Dawsons needed something to feel good about. Shelley was meant to start a new job as a commercial property manager this month but it fell through because of the coronavirus crisis, while Marc has been furloughed from his job as a mechanical supervisor.“We’re busy home schooling and trying to keep Lucy busy,” he says. “She’s an only child and I think she’s getting a bit bored! She misses her friends but she’s working hard at her reading, writing and maths – and she and I love to play football in the garden.”The Dawsons are Norwich City fans, so they were delighted when Lucy won a Community Hero award from the club recently for her flower initiative.And she’s not stopping there. Lucy’s planning to leave handmade cards on neighbours’ doorsteps next.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: monkey cycling kidnap child
story: But the footage, thought to be filmed in Indonesia, may be part of a more sinister form of street entertainment, social media users have claimed.In the clip, a little monkey can be seen speeding down an alley before approaching a group sat on a bench with a toddler.The monkey then abandons the bike and clings onto the youngsters clothing, dragging the child for several feet.The pair scramble before somebody dashes in to rescue the child, forcing the monkey to scamper away.Jasa Supanji, who took the video, told Storyful the child was fine.According to Indonesian news reports the creature is thought to have been involved in a form of street entertainment.And this theory was backed up by social media users - with one Reddit user suggesting it could be quite sinister.They wrote: OK so what really happens is those monkeys get put on a toy bikeand a collar with a rope on it.The owner then yanks the cord so the monkey flies from one end of the street to the other while steering.Pretty cruel and thats probably why the monkey is so strung out. You can see the owner trying to pull back on the cord and he pulls the monkey while it hangs on to the kid, and in the start yanking the cord to propel the bike.Once the theory was shared, users flooded the comments section.One remorseful watcher wrote: Wow, I just rewatched it, and, yes, I absolutely saw the cord. title: kim jong un pool party barge waterslides vip lounge satellite pics
story: Kim is believed to have about  signicant compounds around the country, and numerous luxury vessels.NK News - which focuses on North Korean news - said that new satellite imagery reveals the megaship with an Olympic-size pool used at Kims Wonsan villa last summer.The website says the giant pleasure vessel boasts an  meter-long pool, multi-storey lounge and two huge figure-eight waterslides.Its not clear, however, whether the posh barge is either being decommissioned in Wonsan, or having a refurb.NK News has been comparing satellite pictures of the vessel, going back to  - the year that the US named North Korea as part of an axis of evil.Reuters reported on April  that satellite imagery showed recent movements of luxury boats often used by the North Korean leader and his entourage near Wonsan provided further indications he has been at the coastal resort while he was mysteriously missing.Kim’s seaside compound in Wonsan, on the country’s east coast, is dotted with guest villas and serviced by a private beach, basketball court, and private train station, according to experts and satellite imagery. An airstrip was bulldozed last year to build a horse riding track, while a boathouse nearby shelters Kim’s Princess  luxury yacht, valued at around  million in .Details of his waterpark were also revealed in a rare sketch done by Italian chef Ermanno Furlanis, who worked in Pyong-Yang for the dictator in .Former dictator Kim Jong-Il was often seen at the aquatic park with girls often spotted leaving the luxury barge in a boat.Chef Furlanis, who worked in North Korea for  days, said he had managed to catch glimpses of the barge despite authorities often turning his head so he could not see certain areas of the barge.He told The Sun four years ago: “I think it was for training of the swimmers. The athletes are held in great honour in the country.“They were young athletes, swimmers or basketers.”But he said he also believed the barge was used for “amusement” as well.The experienced chef, who has worked all over the globe, said: “ also some young girl, I saw two, one time the yacht of Kim Il Sung arrived from there.”He said he could not see the detail of the floating park as it wasnt near the kitchen.Cooking for Kim Jung-Il, the leader of North Korea in the late s, the chef said the structure featured a landing bay for smaller boats as well as three floors of accommodation, a guard tower and a waterslide into a pool.The rare sketch revealed that the aquatic park was mobile, moving through the hundreds of islands near the base.From his vantage point of the kitchens, Furlanis said he could see a guard tower on either side of the pool while there were rooms where people could stay and enjoy themselves.The chef said he enjoyed his time working there, telling The Sun: “They have been very polite and gentle with us.”He also said the people were highly refined, and that they appreciated his meals.But he was unable to see much more of the barge or the dictator himself.The chef recalled being ordered to turn his head to avoid seeing Kims yacht arrive.Furlanis said: “I could not even stare at him, they turned myin the other direction.“Nobody could stare at him. It is sacred… like worship.”While the rest of the country was gripped by famine, Furlanis was commissioned along with several other chefs across the world to make international food for the tyrant.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: journalists coronavirus pandemic lockdown save press
story: Nonetheless, there is one indisputable need this crisis has highlighted like no other - the value of journalism. British journalism, in particular.What’s stopping you right now from falling off your perch in fits of laughter  Well, the fact that you’re currently digesting a work of journalism.This probably means that it’s an act – let’s call it that for now – which you’re used to committing on a fairly regular basis.Let’s also assume then that much of the information you gather, store and share comes from such journalistic sources.It’s likely you frequently form opinions and make decisions based on this content you consume.In fact, think really hard for a moment and try and imagine an area of your le where you haven’t been guided in some form by journalism.Buying a house, investing your savings, choosing a school, picking a holiday, deciding which box to put your cross in when you go into a polling booth .If you’re honest with yourself, you tend to make most of those decisions after you’ve digested the array of journalism available to you. And let’s also admit, disregarded too.Some of it is opinion led, some is impartial. You might not agree with all of it, and sometimes you might get ruddy cross at a paper or commentator that doesn’t chime with your world view.But together, the many erse components of British journalism create something which is profoundly valuable.The Covid- pandemic has tested our society to the limit. In the midst of a national crisis, journalists have been putting their lives at risk to keep you informed.News outlets have faithfully broadcast public health announcements – but also held our political leaders to account.The Downing Street daily conference has become a household staple, with ministerial interrogation by the press corps regularly influencing government policy.Without such probing questions and front page splashes, would you have known about the dearth of PPE or the crisis in our care homes Journalism, from local to national level, has connected communities in a way that social networks can only dream of. We have celebrated triumph in the face of adversity – and also documented tributes from the tens of thousands who have lost loved ones.But now we come to the rub.With the country under lockdown, British journalism is facing the biggest threat in its storied history.For newspapers, sales have dramatically fallen. For broadcasters and online outlets, advertising has gone through the floor even whilst audience numbers have risen.Yes, journalism joins one of many industries in financial peril right now.The work of reporters should be held up to scrutiny like any other profession. But we also need to acknowledge the sacrices its practitioners are making to keep the public informed.Everything that journalism hands to you doesn’t come for free.I’m sure that when you think about this properly, in a way you might never have done before, it really is needed more than everWe have to safeguard journalism. It is far too important to discard because it isn’t worth contemplating what the world would look likequality journalism didn’t exist.I don’t need to urge you to buy a paper or take up an online subscription, but I want you to tell everyone you meet that our sector is under a very real and present threat.I am the CEO of the Journalists’ Charity. It was founded in  by Charles Dickens and a group of parliamentary reporters – naturally in a pub.Our core mission to this day remains the same: to bring aid to journalists and their dependents who have fallen on hard times.We are stepping up to the mark, helping those in need with emergency funding and practical and emotional support.It’s why we’ve launched a #supportjournalism campaign in print and on social media.For me, a lockdown without journalists would be unthinkable.That’s why the Journalists’ Charity is standing four-square behind our industry when it needs us most. But we also need you to do your bit too.The Journalists’ Charity has been helping journalists through tough times for more than  years. The charity is currently supporting iniduals from all sectors struggling from the impact of Coronavirus. Register your support here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: hidden cellar home plymouth
story: Jake Brown, from Plymouth, Devon, noticed one wall had dferent textures and decided to inspect further.He drilled a hole in the wall big enough to get his head through it to check the area.When he took a look, Jake discovered there was a huge cellar underneath his home, so he opened the wall to investigate.Inside the tunnel he discovered items including paint cans, a -year-old newspaper as well as bottles from the early s.Jake said: I recently moved into a Georgian property in Emma Place.While having a lazy coffee standing outside the basement front door of the property I noticed a patch in the wall of a texture dferent to the rest.I also noted that the patch was the same distance from the coal cellar already exposed, currently used for storage.Curiosity and a little boredom got the better of me, after which I grabbed a drill and began working pilot viewing holes into the wall.Once I had made two holes, one for viewing, one for a torch, I peered through into the dark dusty expanse and realised that it was another cavern of sorts.After realising what was beneath his house, Jake opened the wall up so that he could climb down and walk inside.He added: I proceeded to hammer out a larger opening through which I could get a better idea of the space, andI should carry on making mess.Upon creating a large enough hole to fit through, I shone a torch into the dark, revealing the larger than expected space before me.The cavern had a lot of builders waste from another era, so I climbed inside to explore and take a closer look.He soon realised the area was bigger than he had expected.Jake added: I measured the rough area of the space and observed its structural integrity.I was pleased to note that the stone arched ceiling was in great condition and the expanse measured a healthy m deep, m high, and m wide.In the area, Jake found piles of building waste and other rubbish, so started digging through it all for clues.He said: Upon inspection it confirmed that the space had been covered up for many years.It had been used as an easy space, to hide the waste from renovating the propertys roof, guttering, doors, and windows many years ago before being covered up.As I moved deeper into the cavern I began to search for evidence that would tie it to a grouping of years so as I could more accurately determine how long it had been covered up.In the dark I collected bottles, paint cans, and my golden find was the remains of a newspaper, though was more comparable to mushy silt.After preparing the newspaper in a bath filled with water, Jake was finally able to open a few pages in search of a date.He added: I laid the items I had collected out in the clear light to identy their age.The paint cans were extremely degraded but had enough detail to show that the labelling was of a s s era style.The bottles, after a quick wipe, were etched with detailing common also of the early s.The biggest reveal was the newspaper, it almost disintegrated upon human touch, so a CSI style method was used to carefully peel back the congealed layers.I proceeded to run a warm bath and soaked the congealed brown mess in the solution for a period of time, after which tweezers and vibration were used to slowly work shards of the paper free while submerged.After as many fragments of the paper had been recovered as possible, I photographed while still submerged and removed what was salvageable for drying.I scanned through the jumbled pieces looking for dates or usable information to determine the era.There were little hints the style of writing, no colour, picture style, currency and then finally a date!What was barely readable was the year , this along with the other pieces of evidence fitted, meaning the cellar had been blocked up for over  years.Armed with evidence, Jake contacted a historian friend, Richard Fisher, to ask for his input.Jake added: That evening I excitedly reached out to a local historian, Mr. Richard Fisher. I described the findings and asked his guidance.Richard said: The whole area before then was a large hill called Windridge Hill for obvious reasons.This was quarried away to almost high tide level, then the houses when built into the hole with cellars, undercrofts etc.However these early cellars, this one looks to be for coal, were built out not only underneath the pavement but out into the road.The load on the roads would have been much lighter than now.I have seen these places turned into wine cellars, a place to grow mushrooms, andbig enough, a grotto type bathing area...

title: joe wicks lockdown jamie oliver
story: RIGHT then, Joe Wicks. He’s just Jamie Oliver with a skipping rope, I assumed, before this wretched lockdown business began.A character we’ve all seen in our local park, with a pair of boxing gloves and a stopwatch, charging financial managers £ a haemorrhoid to do some sit-ups over by the ornamental lake.One of Britain’s ever-growing army of personal trainers who,he wasn’t bouncing around on YouTube every morning, would be clogging up Love Island or Ex On The Beach.That’s what I thought, anyway.Then the coronavirus hit, the local swimming pool shut, the man became a phenomenon and before I could come to my senses, Joe and his infernal timing device were beeping away in my living room, every morning, as I joined in his PE lesson. Inevitably, it didn’t last.First, Joe’s routine did me what I can only describe as “a mischief”.Then, one morning, aged , I caught sight of myself, in a picture frame, doing his “reverse frog shuffle” and thought: “Stuff this for type two diabetes. I’m out.”I’d got no closer to understanding Joe’s astonishing popularity, though, which is truly global.Over , people log in just to stare at his fairly spartan living room, every Monday to Friday.Hundreds of thousands more appear when Joe starts his  minutes of physical jerks.So, in an attempt to unlock the greatest mystery of the outbreak, I kept watching Joe and swtly came to the conclusion success was not linked to his presenting skills.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Because, for a host, he has a strangely distracted and chaotic air about him, with sessions regularly being interrupted by technical issues, forgetfulness and tiny daughter Indie, who charged in, dressed as Zog the dragon, on Friday.He’s not the greatest multitasker either, as Joe often demonstrates with the geography quiz he’s introduced to jolly things along.“What is the capital city of Moscow. . .   No. I mean Russia.”He also has to believe me when I tell him he’s not one of le’s natural comedians.“What’s the capital of Cuba  Fray Bentos. Nah, only joking.”The jokes need to go the same way as the viewers’ poems, in honour of Joe, which he was actually reading out loud, until modesty finally prevailed.Much safer ground is the “spot the dference” competition, which borders on insulting, when he’s merely placed his wall atlas upside down or swapped his electric guitar for a ukulele, but does hint at the drive, ambition and ego behind the man.One day he replaced the atlas with a picture of himself, the next with a picture of his “other house” in Los Angeles and suddenly the penny dropped.Joe’s loaded and his head is not just on its way to Hollywood, it’s already there, making movies and doing squat thrusts with Gwyneth and Brad.The weird thing is, in other presenters, soap actors or comedians, I’d roll my eyes at the folly.With Joe Wicks, I don’t. ’Cos I can’t help it, I quite like him.Part of that may be linked to his no-frills background and a level of personal generosity that’s way beyond most of us .But I like to think it’s got more to do with the fact that, at a time when other cynical, doom-mongering TV hosts are desperately trying to read the public mood, reinvent themselves and force their agenda on viewers, Joe Wicks is just doing what he’s always done. Sit-ups.He may not be Emily Maitlis , but he’s the irrepressible and lucky optimist telling us to get off our fat a***s when we need to hear it most.He’s temporarily indisposed at the moment, of course.A gammy arm means we Rosie is leading the workouts.But I was firmly of the opinion nothing and no one could ever stand in the way of world domination, until I tuned into Sunday night’s Diva On Lockdown and there was Gemma Collins trying to contort her mighty bulk into one of Joe’s squats while she bellowed: “I wonder how Joe Wicks would feelhe knew the GC was doing his workout ”Beaten, I’d imagine.He must never know.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.And her face is glued to the back of her head.So there will be hell to payit comes unstuck on The Real Marigold Hotel, where the only other one of the eight celebs who’s appeared looking as unearthly as Britt is former Dragons’ Den star Duncan Bannatyne, whose hair is now a “vibrant and colourful” shade of roast papaya orange. And will remain that way, until the monsoon breaks.It’s probably safe to say neither of them will be hanging around that long, though, or “retiring to India” any time soon.This is the fourth series of the BBC show and not one of the famous pensioners has given the place a second look yet.They have, however, all come home alive.So I wish the Beeb would count its lucky stars, cut the pretence, make Duncan pay for everyone’s holiday and let us all enjoy their discomfort, which is considerable and very entertaining.During the first episode: John “Nasty Nick” Altman proved as supple as Tower Bridge at his first ever yoga lesson.Paul Chuckle remained confined to barracks with the trots.Henry “Blowers” Blofeld rejected insect repellent on the grounds that: “Mosquitoes get p***edthey bite me.”And actress Susie Blake certainly didn’t hold back when the local foot doctor told her: “You have some unwanted growths.”“Yes, I have haemorrhoids.”Susie, too much inflammation.Jamie Redknapp: “We always used to turn up late but somehow we’d make it in time.Martin Keown: “Vieira was the best I ever played with. But Henry was a great player, so don’t make me choose between them.”Paul Merson: “The secret to working hard is to work hard.”ON one particularly fraught episode of her Channel  show, last week, Steph McGovern was forced to let a wasp out of her living room window, live on air.Probably halving her audience in the process.A day later it was announced the show itself was being released back into the wild, or as they put it “taking a break”.Credit for this development was being given to Steph’s long-suffering neighbours, who’d objected to the disruption the production had caused and may yet get a Bafta fellowship for their intervention.Truth be told, though, Steph’s “power hour of positivity” was more likely killed by worthiness, lack of content, technical issues and the host herself, who’s a rotten interviewer, kills every good joke stone dead, has the same set response to everythingand a terrible habit of asking exactly the wrong question.“Martin , what are you doing with all that toilet paper ” “Errr . . . ”There’s talk of a brave new dawn, in a shiny Leeds studio, later this year and when I last checked, author Marian Keyes was giving some pointed advice on how to become a good novelist: “Your first efforts will be woefully appalling. It’s like anything in le you want to be good at. Keep showing up.”Steph. Don’t.MORE now from Russell Grant’s “uncannily accurate”  predictions in December’s Mirror.“Scorpio — travel will be a great source of joy for you in April.”Yeah, April. How’d that work out for you Netflix thriller series Fauda. Channel ’s SAS: Who Dares Wins . title: social distancing lockdown workplace schools
story: RADICAL measures to prevent the spread of coronavirus in workplaces will be in place for up to a year, The Sun has been told.Screens between desks, staff sitting back-to-back and a ban on hot desking and sharing of equipment are among moves employers must introduce when lockdown is lted.The new measures — proposed in draft documents on ato workplaces — also require staggered sht times to avoid crowding on public transport.Handwashing kit must be at entry and exit points, with regular cleaning of worktops. Yellow and black tape will tell people where to stand in lts.One-way systems will be the norm in offices and on train s and at bus stops.Face-to-face meetings will only be able to go aheadabsolutely necessary and be time-limited.Employees will even be told not to share stationary such as pens.The message to employers is to allow their staff to work from homethey’re not needed in the workplace.It means home-working will likely become the default for millions of Brits for the foreseeable future.But employers will have to monitor the well-being of staff working from home by keeping in touch to ask about their welfare, physical health and personal security.The Government has told industry groups the new measures will have to be in place for between six and  months.They were told there will be a “gradual winding down” after the winter, The Sun has learnt.It is understood the y timeframe has been influenced by growing fears among the Government’s medical advisers that the coronavirus is seasonal.An industry source said: “If it survives the winter, these measures will have to be in place longer.”But one positive industry bosses are drawing from the new measures is the impact it will have on dampening traditional flu.The draft papers cover seven dferent settings: offices, hotel and restaurants, shops, factories, outdoor workplaces and those who work in vehicles and other people’s homes.Staggered sht times, less sharing of equipment and continued maximisation of home working are among a number of ideas listed as part of a draft government strategy to help businesses prepare for ato work.Increased hygiene procedures and the installation of protective screens are also included in the plan.Efforts to avoid employees working face-to-face will see them working side by side or facing away from each other, according to the plans leaked to Buzzfeed News.There will be limits on the number of people in stores so Brits will be asked to shop alone to enable shops to be allowed to open and kick-start the economy.The advice for reopening non-essential shops such as clothes stores will be similar to the supermarket rules.Tape setting out two metre distances will have to be put on shop floors, and Brits will need to queue outside.Many shops will go cashless to stop the spread of the virus through money.In cities like London, maintaining the two-metre rule would make it impossible for workplaces to operate anywhere near full capacity.Platforms and bus stops will contain two metre markers to maintain social distancing and one-way systems will be in place.A complex blueprint for schools to open in waves of dferent age groups is being planned.Reopening primary schools is a priority for the Government in order to minimise the threat to early years development and help parentsto work. But Year  pupils will be first backthey are forced to stagger the reopening dates as they are at the most crucial stage of their learning.PM Boris Johnson wants the first schools to reopen on June .Year  and  pupils are expected to be the first wave of secondary schools to open.No firm date has been set for reopening workplaces but The Sun revealed last week that May  has been pencilled in as a target date as long as the Government’s five tests for lting the lockdown measures are met by then.Mr Johnson will publish a “roadmap” strategy on Sunday, detailing exactly how restrictions will be eased in order for Brits to safelyto work.Defence Secretary Ben Wallace said measures such as shields, masks and limiting the amount of contact time with colleagues could be alternative approaches taken by employers.But the draft guidance did not contain details about what personal protective equipment staff should wear when theyto work.The Trades Union Congress refused to support the plans as they stand, saying they “fall far short of giving any guarantees to workers about their health and safety”.Ministers confirmed that the Government has started stockpiling face masks for public use.Scotland boss Nicola Sturgeon revealed she shares Boris Johnsons hopes of being able to start easing the coronavirus lockdown towards the end of May.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: healthy over 70s to be freed from strict lockdown
story: OVER-s should be able to self-select whether they are vulnerable or not once the lockdown is eased, ministers have said.It follows criticism that using age-based criteria to lt restrictions would lead to social unrest.About . million clinically vulnerable people have been told they must stay in lockdown for at least  weeks, with some ministers saying they might need to remain at home until there is a vaccine, which could take a year or more.They include people aged  or older regardless of medical conditions and those under  with an underlying health condition.As the government reviews its lockdown policy, British Medical Association and the Royal College of GPs said a wholesale lockdown of the elderly was discriminatory and unacceptable.Former minister Baroness Ros Altmann, , said Britain faces social unrestthe over-s are forced to live in a longer lockdown than younger generations.The Conservative peer said many older people would risk going to prison rather than being forced to isolate at home.Charity Director at Age UK Caroline Abrahams also spoke out against blanket policies based on age.Comedian Sir Michael Palin, , agreed in a separate interview that age restrictions would be very dficult and very wrong and very unfair.Amid the criticism, a minister close to the discussions concerning elderly and vulnerable people told thethe over-s will self-select whether they are vulnerable or not.They told the newspaper: The all over-s grouping is going to morph. There is a big dference between the . million shielded people, known as extremely critically vulnerable, who have been sent a letter advising them to shield for  weeks, vulnerable people with pre-existing health conditions of any age, and healthy over-s.This needs to be made clearer – you cant just have a blanket over-s group. Thats unsustainable. Its not a static group.The minister added: There arent enough supermarket delivery slots to cater for that amount of people.What we are going to see is more self-selection and personal responsibility.People will self-select whether they are vulnerable or not. The over-s are a very sensible group – by and large, they knowthey should be staying indoors or not.Meanwhile Tory Sir Graham Brady said on Monday night: We have today the most healthiest, active elderly generation of all time and it would be tragicGovernment threatened this by trying to extend a so-called lockdown for those judged to be most at risk based on age.Why dont we just give them the best information and advice and let them limit their risk themselves In the original Government guidance, anyone over , regardless of their state of health, was advised to be particularly stringent in following social distancing measures.But on May , that was withdrawn and replaced with new advice which listed all over-s as clinically vulnerable.Amid confusion over the guidelines, Health Secretary Matt Hancock tweeted: The clinically vulnerable, who are advised to stay in lockdown for  weeks, emphatically DO NOT include all over-s.The Department of Health and Social Care confirmed over s are not included in the most at risk group , who have been told to isolate for  weeks.On Monday, the Prime Ministers official spokesman said: Over-s are classed as being in the clinically vulnerable group – they are not necessarily in the clinically extremely vulnerable group, which are those people who are shielding.Therefore the advice to them is to take particular care to minimise contact with others outside their household.Asked whether the over-s would have dferent rules from other sections of the population, the spokesman added: We know that, as you get older, there is a higher risk of coronavirus having a more serious impact. Complications and deaths are more common in the elderly, even those without pre-existing conditions.But as we look forward it is perfectly reasonable that we will look at how guidance will apply for dferent age bands, and we will continue to be guided by the science.The UK coronavirus death toll hit , on Monday as another  patients died in the lowest rise in more than a month.The last time the UK recorded such a low  hour fatality rate was almost five weeks ago on March  when  deaths were reported.However there is often a drop in Mondays figures due to a lag in reporting over the weekend with Tuesdays number likely to be higher.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ten ways honour ve day 75 years katherine jenkins vera lynn
story: To keep social distancing, there will be no audience in the venue during the classical singer’s half-hour rendition of wartime favourites, including a virtual duet of We’ll Meet Again with Dame Vera Lynn, .And Katherine’s solo concert, which will be broadcast on YouTube, won’t be the only celebration on Friday.The Sun is calling on YOU to lt the country’s spirits by putting on the best stay-at-home parties.It’s your chance to have fun while paying tribute to -year-old fund-raising hero Colonel Tom Moore and all the other World War Two veterans who fought for our freedom. Before lockdown, the early May Bank Holiday was moved to Friday to give millions of us a three-day break.And we are not going to let Covid- stop us from marking this special day – just like millions of Brits did on May , , when Nazi Germany’s surrender ended war in Europe.From wonderful wartime songs to fabulous food and games, our guide will help you put on a party.We’ve also included a TV guide and the lyrics to Dame Vera’s anthem so you can join in with a national singalong after the Queen addresses the nation.It’s going to be a day to remember for all the family.So will you please say helloWe’ll meet againWe’ll meet againKeep smiling throughSo will you please say helloWe’ll meet againSINGER Katherine Jenkins took part in celebrations that were staged  and  years after VE Day – and she is proud to perform again during these dficult times.She said: “While we may not be able to celebrate this year as we once did, it’s only right that we don’t allow the th anniversary of this historic day to be overshadowed.“I wanted to do something to help bring the nation and the world together in commemoration and celebration at this dficult time.“I’m excited that we can still come together, albeit virtually, for a tribute of wartime songs and musical memories from London’s most iconic concert venue.“The Royal Albert Hall will be seen like never before – empty, isolated and yet still breathtakingly magnicent.”Katherine will sing wartime favourites The White Clfs Of Dover and We’ll Meet Again – referenced by the Queen in her coronavirus address when she urged the nation to “remain united and resolute”.Dame Vera, now  years old, says: “I hope this special duet lts the spirits of our VE Day veterans and all those separated from loved ones at this time.”The performance starts at pm on Friday.To find out how to watch, see royalalberthall ve.THERE were many tunes that kept the nation going during the dark days of war.Here’s our top ten. You can listen to them by searching for each one on YouTube.PAUSE to raise a glass at pm – that’s when Dame Joan Collins is going to lead the nation’s toast from the balcony of her London home.She will pay tribute to women in the war during her public address which is expected to be covered by TV news networks.The -year-old actress, who is also appearing on Lorraine on ITV earlier in the morning, said: “We must never forget the selflessness of all those who sacriced so much to keep us free during the Second World War.”Here is The Sun’s very own toast to the nation . . .To the heroes of the Second World War, we salute you.To the heroes of the war against Covid-, we thank you.THERE are plenty of traditional games that the whole family can play at your VE Day party. Here are some of the most enjoyable.MUSICAL BUMPS: The children dance around in the centre of the room. When the music stops, they must sit on the floor as quickly as possible. The last one to sit down is eliminated.CHARADES: Split into two teams and take it in turns to act out your favourite films, songs, TV shows or sports.But try not to make them too dficult!MUSICAL STATUES: While music plays everyone moves around, either dancing, hopping or skipping, then freezes when it stops.The first one to move is eliminated.The music is re-started and the process repeated until a winner is crowned.HIDE AND SEEK: Probably the most-loved children’s game of all time – and you don’t need any equipment to play it.One player closes their eyes and counts up to  while the other players hide.The seeker then tries to find the hiders.The first one found is the next seeker and the last is the winner of the round.Test your knowledge of VE Day with our fun quiz:HANG out the bunting – a few rows of colourful triangular flags add a dash of fun to your decorations. Get the whole family involved.Encourage your children to cut out triangles from anything they can find around the house – scrap paper, empty cereal boxes, string, ribbon or even sweet wrappers. They can colour the shapes in with felt-tip pens.You could even dig out old Christmas decorations and adapt them.The BBC’s Make A Dference campaign has some great ideas for making bunting.There is even a template you can download.To find out more, see bbc makeadference.Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, pictured, who lost both legs and suffered brain damage when his armoured Land Rover hit a mine in Afghanistan in , is backing the BBC initiative.He says: “Join me and make great British bunting.”TRY making some wartime grub. With rationing and food shortages, the nation had to make the best of what was available in .Lord Woolton Pie was a favourite, containing potatoes or parsnips, carrots, caullower, swede and sometimes turnips, all topped with potato pastry and grated cheese. Also popular was Homity Pie – a pastry case containing potatoes, onions and leeks topped with cheese.Meat dishes included dripping sandwiches with beef fat, pork faggots with onion gravy and mash, liver casserole and corned beef hash.While butter and many other kitchen basics were rationed during World War Two, beer never was as it was considered essential for the nation’s morale.That’s probably why our troops showed so much bottle!YOU can’t go wrong with this delicious cake recipe. There are just a few easy steps and it takes only  minutes to bake.Heat your oven to C fan C gas . Butter two cm sandwich tins and line with non-stick baking paper.In a large bowl, beat g caster sugar, g softened butter,  beaten eggs, g self-raising flour,  tsp baking powder and  tbsp milk together until you have a smooth, soft batter.Divide the mixture between the tins and smooth the surface with the back of a spoon. Bake for  mins until golden brown.Take out of the oven and leave to cool completely.To make the filling, beat the g softened butter until smooth and creamy then beat in g sted icing sugar.Spread the buttercream over the bottom of one of the sponges.Top it with g strawberry jam and sandwich the second sponge on top.Dust with icing sugar before serving.It will keep for two days, but you’ll want to eat it straight away.IT’S a right royal day of telly with The Queen leading the way. Here’s the pick of the best viewing.am, BBC:The Nation Remembers. A two-minute silence to mark the th anniversary of the end of the conflict in Europe. This national moment of remembrance will pay tribute to heroes of the past and present..pm-.pm, BBC: The Announcement Of Victory. Military music, personal testimony and readings feature in this tribute to the Second World War generation. It includes Sir Winston Churchill’s historic victory speech in which he addressed the nation to announce the end of the war in Europe, which he made from  Downing Street on May , .pm-pm, BBC: The One Show. Alex Jones and guests celebrate the th anniversary of VE Day.pm-pm, Channel : The Lost Films. Eyewitness accounts and cine films of ordinary people charting that extraordinary day  years ago when the nation took to the streets in spontaneous celebrations.pm-.pm, ITV: Captain Tom’s War: Memories of the brutal Burma campaign that has become known as the forgotten war.pm-.pm, BBC:The People’s Celebration. Recollections and music of the Second World War, featuring Katherine Jenkins, Adrian Lester, Anton du Beke, Beverley Knight, Shane Richie and actress Emma Barton.At pm on the programme, Her Majesty the Queen addresses the nation followed by a national singalong when everyone is invited to join in with We’ll Meet Again as a way of saying thank you to the brave veterans who fought in World War Two.pm-pm, Discovery Channel: Tony Robinson’s VE Day Minute By Minute. Documentary painting an evocative picture of a nation celebrating the declaration of peace..pm-pm, BBC: Remembering Victory. Famous names share memories of VE Day. Narrated by Julie Walters and featuring David Attenborough. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Officials in Beijing shut down wet markets after early cases of the coronavirus were linked to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in Wuhan.Wet markets were able to resume trading as of mid-April.The Chinese government banned the breeding, trading and selling of wild animals in February, but has yet to publish a full list of what is considered wild.The law has yet to become permanent as officials are looking for what the public thinks is wild animal or livestock.So far  animals are considered exemptions from the ban including cattle, pigs, poultry and camels.There are further  species that would fall under the special tag and also be exempt and those include: reindeer, alpaca, pheasants, ostriches and foxes.The full list isnt expected to be finalised until mid-May and until then it appears openly selling wild animals can resume.It is understood most animals like frogs, turtles and scorpions are on a list of banned animals - which came into effect on May .It comes after a video taken at the Tomohon Traditional Market in North Sulawesi, Indonesia, has emerged showing butchers carving up animals in the open and customers free to roam through the crowds.The coronavirus is believed to have emerged from such a market in the city of Wuhan late last year.Wet markets traditionally sell fresh produce and live animals, such as fish and exotic animals, which are butchered in the open air.They tend to be popular with shoppers who believe the items on sale are cheaper and fresher than in supermarkets.But theyre poorly regulated.The suspected source of the killer bug, the Huanan Seafood Market, has not reopened.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - title: boris must ease lockdown soon
story: Boris Johnson cannot be sure the NHS would not be swamped by a second wave of infections.He has, though, taken out comprehensive insurance: The expansion of health service capacity was so huge that it can now afford to shut the new ,-bed Nightingale Hospital in London and place it on standby.The PM’s “unlockdown” decision was urgent even before the grim news of two million new benefit claims. Our formerly thriving economy is on its knees, losing billions a day. Huge numbers of jobs have been lost, many permanently.Matt Hancock’s new “track and trace” app may prove a great addition to the armoury against Covid- and we urge every Sun reader to download and use it when available. But we cannot wait for such tactics to bear fruit in the statistics.We are past the peak. Deaths are on their way down. The NHS was nowhere near being overwhelmed and that looks increasingly unlikely.The Government must not be swayed by the lockdown’s continued public support. That will evaporate once the long-term economic consequences sink in.We strongly disagree, though, with those who never thought it necessary — and make spurious comparisons of our death totals against countries of very dferent sizes and population densities.And we know what a tough call this is. But easing us imminently back to work and school, using social distancing and masks, is the right one. Yes, an NHS unable to cope would be a catastrophe.An even greater one is a prolonged lockdown . . . and a nation engulfed by bankruptcies, unemployment and poverty.WHAT a golden excuse the lockdown has been for every bossy busybody to exercise their authoritarian urges.Even so, we never imagined anyone would be mean-spirited enough to moan about the weekly clap for our ­carers — let alone for local councils to act on such petty grievances.One, however, has issued a warning to tone down the applause and Vera Lynn songs after a single complaint. title: half of adults paid by state
story: Chancellor Rishi Sunaks furlough scheme to pay  per cent of wages up to £, a month cost an eyewatering £billion in the first month - just shy of the NHS monthly budget of £billion.It means a staggering million adults are now dependent on the state for at least part of their income.Yesterdays figures showed another , out-of-work Brits have made claims for Jobseekers Allowance as the economy is ravaged by the Covid- lockdown.The jaw-dropping numbers come on top of .million people who were already unemployed, .million public sector workers and .million people who receive a state pension.It means more than  million people from an adult population of just over million - or around  per cent of the country - is now state-funded.Last night, Mr Sunak admitted the cost to the taxpayer was clearly not a sustainable situation.Mr Sunak said: To anyone who is anxious about this, I want to give them reassurance today that there will be no clf edge to the furlough scheme.Im working, as we speak, to figure out the most effective way to wind down the [furlough] scheme and to ease people back into work in a measured way.As some scenarios have suggested, we are potentially spending as much on the furlough scheme as we do on the NHS, for example. Clearly that is not a sustainable situation.Altogether, , companies made claims covering . million jobs under the furlough program, the Prime Ministers spokesman announced.Yesterdays figures dont include five million self-employed Brits who can apply for a grant of up to £, a month.The devastating numbers lay bare the economic impact of the virus as Boris Johnson prepares to announce a road map out of Britains lockdown.Under the PM’s blueprint to end the nation’s virtual house arrest, the whole nation will see the tough restrictions begin to be eased at the same time, with the end of May targeted.The lockdown was announced in March to curb the spread of the virus, which has killed more than , Brits.Yesterdays daily death toll was the lowest rise for five weeks, with  more people dying in the UK.But Mr Johnson is under pressure from some quarters to ease the shutdown, which has wreaked havoc on firms and employees.Sir Iain Duncan Smith, the former Conservative leader and former work and pensions secretary, told The : This proves that we have to now be looking to unlock the lockdown urgently because this is unsustainable for much longer.Sir John Redwood, a former Cabinet minister, said: In a short-term crisis the state needs to pay people who cannot work.[But] furlough has to be a temporary measure. title: wolf of wall street wannabe
story: Jordan Homer, , totalled his flash motor just four months after buying it when he flipped over on the M near Winchester, Hants.But the trader later quipped to his , Instagram followers that at least his pricey Gucci slider flip flops had survived the crash.Jordan, from Southampton, said: “It was a second hand car worth £,, but it will be a write-off.“Surprisingly I’ve only got a small cut on my body - I probably put my hand on a bit of glass as obviously the car was upside down.He added: “A lot of people have noticed my Gucci slider which was in my boot and it slapped my face as we were flipping around and landed on my lap.“You’ve got to look at the bright side of these thingsI get upset about everything then it’s going to be an issue and people are going to be like ‘oh you’re crying’, so I thought I’d remain positive.”Jordan lost control when his car aquaplaned - something police say was caused by his use of incorrect tyres.Hampshire Constabulary said the tyres didn’t meet the minimum required tread depth and this was why his BMW flipped.Jordan claims to earn a six figure salary Forex trading and his Instagram is littered with photos of him posing with Dom Perignon champagne and Rolexes in front of iconic landmarks and idyllic beach views.Other photos show him gloating over wads of cash and parading round his Louis Vuitton shopping bags.However, followers on social media have accused him of being irresponsible and said he should have splashed his cash on safer tyres instead of designer gear.One follower called him a “donut” and advised him to invest his high salary in some driving lessons, while another branded him as a “Wolf of Wall Street wannabe” - but one that “couldn’t afford tyres for his car”.Jordan disputes that his tread depth was illegal and explained that he was out and about during lockdown to pick up a bike for exercise – not flouting social distancing rules.Jordan said: “It’s frustrating as [its been made out online to] make me seem like the young person disobeying the laws going out when social distancing - it was a completely necessary trip.“I did everything correctly and it was just unfortunate that I was in the wrong place at the wrong time.”Hants Road Policing blamed the tyres for the accident and said the vehicle lost control due to lack of grip and aquaplaned.They tweeted: Please check the inside as well as outside tread of your tyres. Especiallyyou have high power rear wheel drive car with wide wheels.This one was under the legal tread depth which will explain why its now upside down. No injuries this time thankfully.Hampshire Constabulary said Jordan’s tyres did not meet the minimum required tread depth - but he claims they were well over the limit and that he is pursuing overturning the three points on his licence with police.Jordan said: “The police said there was nobody at fault it was just one of those things - aquaplaning happens.“The tires are absolutely fine - the police measured the rest of the treads and they were all about mm worth of tread depth - which is .mm over the legal requirements.A spokesman for Hampshire Constabulary said: “We were called just before .pm to a report of a vehicle overturned on the hard shoulder of the M southbound between junctions  and  near Winchester.No injuries were reported. The driver was reported for having tyres which did not meet the minimum required tread depth.”

title: colour pictures ve day
story: Proud Brits will commemorate the th anniversary since the end of World War II in Europe on May , .Images in the collection show Winston Churchill being swarmed by joyous brits, a street party taking place in Manchester and a group of Londoners crammed onto an RAF lorry posing with victory symbols and smiles.Another picture shows a group of  schoolchildren posing at a V for victory shaped table.The term VE day was first coined as early as September , to honour the eventual date of the second world war in Europe.On May , , fighting drew to a halt as the Germans surrendered to the allies, marking the end of Adolf Hitler’s war and sparking celebrations around the world.The event is regarded as one of the biggest celebrations in British history.It commemorates the formal acceptance of Nazi Germany’s surrender by the allied forces at the end of the Second World War.On  April , Adolf Hitler committed suicide.Karl Dönitz succeeded him as the German head of state, going on to negotiate an end to the war with the allied forces, which was made up of nations including Britain, the US, France and Russia.It heralded the beginning of the end of the Second World War, a conflict that cost millions of lives.

title: new zealand pm closed borders

title: obese people work from home coronavirus
story: OBESE Brits may have to work from home under a draft plan to lt Britains coronavirus lockdown, a leaked Government document shows.Severely overweight people could be classied as vulnerable along with over-s and pregnant women and forced to stay indoors.Companies may have to find a new role for vulnerable people forced to work from home during the pandemic.Around three in ten adults are clinically obese in England, one of the highest rates in the western world.Scientists believe obese patients are more at risk from Covid- as their immune systems are weaker.Speaking yesterday, Health Secretary Matt Hancock said there was possibly a link between obesity and the impact of Covid-.Mr Hancock said: Our knowledge about this virus grows daily and it appears some groups are more affected than others.Emerging data from around the world suggests there could possibly be a relationship between obesity and the impact of Covid- on iniduals.Its too early to sayobesity in itself is a factor or conditions associated with it – or there is not enough data yet to rule it out – so we need to approach any assumptions with caution.Every death from this virus is a tragedy and behind each statistic is a name, a loss and a family that will never be the same again.The radical measures to prevent the spread of Covid- in workplaces will be in place for up to a year, The Sun has been told.Screens between desks, staff sitting back-to-back and a ban on hot desking and sharing of equipment are among moves employers must introduce when lockdown is lted.The new measures — proposed in draft documents on ato workplaces — also require staggered sht times to avoid crowding on public transport.Handwashing kit must be at entry and exit points, with regular cleaning of worktops. facing away from each other, according to the plans leaked to Buzzfeed News.There will be limits on the number of people in stores so Brits will be asked to shop alone to enable shops to be allowed to
